channel.title: Comments on: Dealing with A transport-level error has occurred when sending the request to the server errors
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Michael Habib
item.dc:creator: Michael Habib
item.description:
I had this error in SQL Server 2012
A transport-level error has occurred when sending the request to the server. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 - An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.) (Microsoft SQL Server, Error: 10054)
*********Problem Solved************* I changed the SQL Service Account from a domain account to a local one. *********Problem Solved*************
item.content:encoded:
I had this error in SQL Server 2012

A transport-level error has occurred when sending the request to the server. (provider: TCP Provider, error: 0 – An existing connection was forcibly closed by the remote host.) (Microsoft SQL Server, Error: 10054)

*********Problem Solved*************
I changed the SQL Service Account from a domain account to a local one.
*********Problem Solved*************

item.title: By: Mark White
item.dc:creator: Mark White
item.content:encoded:
Explanation:

SQL Server has trashed it’s thread that was tied to your SSMS query window and released all resources tied to it (Usually because SQL Server has restarted or someone has killed your process in SQL Activity Monitor).

When you try to run the first time, nothing will happen because SSMS thinks you’re still connected. The second time you run the query, this will force a re-connect and open everything back up, allowing you to query away.
